Presenting Problem / Chief Complaint: The patient reports feeling anxious due to stressful circumstances and financial worries, which contribute to feelings of losing ground and discomfort
Substance Use History: The patient self-medicates to sleep, indicating potential issues with sleep management
History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient has been experiencing anxiety related to financial instability and has a history of depressive symptoms
Medical and Psychiatric History: The patient identifies as a classic depressive and has been seeing a therapist for about six years, who does not prescribe medications
Psychosocial History: The patient has been married for 24 years, has a high-achieving daughter, and describes their relationship as strained due to sleeping arrangements
Mental Health Observations: The patient expresses feelings of anxiety and difficulty coping with stress, indicating a need for ongoing support
Physiological Observations: The patient reports waking up earlier than desired and experiencing sluggishness when not getting enough sleep
Current Functional Status: The patient describes coping well but acknowledges reduced functionality when sleep-deprived
Diagnostic Impressions: The patient exhibits symptoms consistent with anxiety and depression, requiring further evaluation and support
Progress Evaluation: The patient finds therapy beneficial and looks forward to sessions, indicating a positive therapeutic relationship
Therapeutic Interventions: Continued therapy sessions to address anxiety and depressive symptoms
Next Steps: Explore coping strategies for anxiety and sleep management, while monitoring financial stressors
